text:
So we're going to move on
to our next type of data.

And this data is thankfully
a little less grisly.

It's talking about the
time it takes to have
a clinical trial published.

So as we mentioned
earlier, this is--

while survival
analysis is often used

in biostatistics literature
for actual survival time--

that's why the term
survival is in the title--

it's a general use
purpose for timed data.

And so here we're going
to use a data that's

not actual survival,
just how long it
takes to get a paper published.
OK.

So one of the
features we're going

to look at on a
categorical variable
is this posres feature.

That stands for
positive results.

So when a-- whether the clinical
trial finished with a, well,

a positive result maybe for a
treatment or a negative result

for a treatment, or it
depends on what the study--

It says whether the
trial was successful.
The trial was set out to--
Establish something.
--establish something.
Yes, yeah.
And either it did or it didn't.
So let's take a look at these.

We have a-- result equals
0, that's a negative result.

And a result equals 1
is a positive result.

So we can see that negative
results, some of them
just never get published.

And that's well known in
the scientific literature

that it's hard to publish a
negative result because, well--

So in this example,
a high hazard

is good because it's the
time to the event, which
is publication.
Yes.

So, again, we can
fit a Cox model.

If we want to do a logrank
test or something close to it,

we could do it
with the Cox model.

So this is very
similar to what we

saw before looking at sex
for the different survival
in the cancer data.

So the p value is
not significant.

And you can see from the plot
that even though it looks

like there's a
bit of separation,

the standard errors
are quite wide and--

Yeah, and for this
region here, there's
not much of a difference.

There's not much
difference, right.
Yeah.

So if we had come
up with a hypothesis

that there's a difference
in this period,

we might have had a
significant p value.

But the Cox-- the logrank test
looks at the entire survival
curve.

So now we're going to include
some of the other features.

So we're going to
drop this mech.
It's the funding mechanism used.

I guess that's whether it's
NIH, or privately funded,
or NSF and fit a Cox model.
So now the-- let's see.

Oh, there's some significant
things there, Jonathan.

Yeah, posres becomes
significant now.

Impact, so this is
some measure of the--
I guess this is post hoc.

Once the paper is
published, you can

measure its impact
and studies that were
published relatively quickly.

And some are associated
with having high impact.

That's what we can
glean from this one.

And similarly, now that the
effect for positive results

is stronger, the p
value is smaller.
So that's interesting.
That happens sometimes.

When you look at a
variable just on its own,

it might be not
significant because there's

other things going on,
confounding factors that
interfere with the variable.

And now when you put
in all these variables,
posres now looks significant.
Yeah.

Like in a linear
regression context,

allowing for these
other variables
can reduce the extra variation.

And then the difference can
appear more significant.
OK.

So there's a third example,
which is on call center data.
And this is simulated data.

And the analysis is very
similar to what we've done.

And so we'll leave
that one for you.
Yes.

We'll just note that the one
new thing in this call center

data you'll see is that there's
a multivariate logrank test.

You can work by
analogy with the--

the logrank test is used when
you have a categorical variable
with two levels.

Here we have some categorical
variables with three levels.

And for that, instead of the
2 by 2 table of the logranks,

there will be a 2 by
3 or a 3 by 2 table.

And that's the
multivariate logrank test.

But the interpretation
is quite similar.

So we'll leave that
for you to do offline.
